title: What is the connection between Dante's "bello stilo" and his code of behavior, as influenced by Virgil and Pythagorean thought?
first_phrase: In this part of the text, the author delves deeper into the concept of the "beautiful style" as described by Dante, adding a new layer of meaning to the term. The author argues that Dante's idea of style is not limited to literary expression but encompasses a way of life, drawing a parallel between Dante and Virgil's morality and behavior. The author references several texts, including Plato's theory of ideas, Carcopino's work on Virgil, and the ideas of numerologists like Marsilio Ficino and Pico della Mirandola. The main argument is that Dante's concept of the "beautiful style" is linked to a higher moral and spiritual ideal that incorporates both literary and life-related aspects.

Anche il Cardinale Cusa (De docta ignorantia, I, 5) asserisce: non potest autem unitas esse numerus; sed est principium omnis numeri. Dicendo Uno Dio (dicono Ambrogio e Tommaso, Summa, I, 30, 3) non si vuole esprimere un valore quantitativo ma un valore assolutamente qualitativo.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the study of numbers and their symbolism has a long history dating back to ancient Greece and has influenced great thinkers and artists throughout the ages. From Plato's theory of ideas to Leonardo da Vinci's divine symmetry, the fascination with numerology continues to inspire and captivate us today. For those interested in exploring this field further, the works of Robin, Carcopino, Marsilio Ficino, and Giordano Bruno are recommended reading.
